description: Execute commands repeatedly at intervals - learn continuous monitoring

tasks.title: Basic Watch Usage
tasks.description: Monitor disk usage by running 'df -h' every 2 seconds. What command repeats other commands at intervals?
hints: Use 'watch' followed by the command to repeat
tasks.explanation: The 'watch' command repeatedly executes other commands at regular intervals, showing updated output.

tasks.title: Custom Interval
tasks.description: Monitor system load average every 5 seconds using uptime. How do you change the watch interval?
hints: Use '-n' followed by seconds for custom interval
tasks.explanation: The '-n' option sets the interval in seconds. You can use decimal values for sub-second intervals.

tasks.title: Watch Process List
tasks.description: Monitor the top 10 processes by CPU usage, updating every 3 seconds.
hints: head -11 shows header plus top 10 processes
tasks.explanation: Use quotes around complex commands with pipes or redirections when using watch.

tasks.title: Highlight Differences
tasks.description: Monitor a log file size and highlight when it changes using watch.
hints: Changes are shown in reverse video
tasks.explanation: The '-d' option highlights differences between successive command outputs.

tasks.title: Watch with No Title
tasks.description: Monitor network connections without showing the watch command header.
hints: Use '-t' to turn off the title/header
Gives more screen space for output
tasks.explanation: The '-t' option removes the header, providing more space for command output.

tasks.title: Watch Memory Usage
tasks.description: Monitor memory usage with detailed statistics every second.
hints: echo adds blank line for readability
tasks.explanation: Combine multiple commands to create comprehensive monitoring displays.

tasks.title: Watch File Changes
tasks.description: Monitor a configuration file for changes, showing file size and modification time.
hints: Use stat to show file metadata
tasks.explanation: Monitor file attributes to detect changes in configuration files or logs.

tasks.title: Watch with Exit on Change
tasks.description: Monitor a process until it disappears, then exit watch automatically.
hints: Use '-g' to exit when output changes
Useful for waiting for process completion
tasks.explanation: The '-g' option exits watch when the command output changes, useful for process monitoring.

tasks.title: Watch Directory Contents
tasks.description: Monitor a directory for new files, showing count and newest file.
tasks.explanation: Create custom monitoring displays using command substitution and formatting.

tasks.title: Watch with Color Output
tasks.description: Monitor system processes with colored output preserved.
hints: Use --color to preserve ANSI color codes
Some commands need -c or --color flag too
tasks.explanation: The --color option preserves colored output from commands that support it.

tasks.title: Watch Network Activity
tasks.description: Monitor network interface statistics with bandwidth calculations.
tasks.explanation: Monitor network interface statistics by parsing system files with watch.

tasks.title: Watch with Beep Alert
tasks.description: Monitor disk space and beep when usage exceeds 80%.
hints: Use '-b' to beep when command output changes
awk filters lines based on conditions
tasks.explanation: The '-b' option creates audio alerts when command output changes, useful for threshold monitoring.

tasks.title: Watch System Temperature
tasks.description: Monitor CPU temperature every 5 seconds with threshold highlighting.
tasks.command: watch -n 5 -d 'sensors | grep Core || echo "sensors not available"'
hints: Use || for fallback when command unavailable
tasks.explanation: Monitor hardware sensors with fallback options when tools aren't available.

tasks.title: Watch Log File Growth
tasks.description: Monitor log file growth rate by tracking line count and file size.
tasks.explanation: Create comprehensive log monitoring by combining multiple file statistics.

tasks.title: Watch with Precise Timing
tasks.description: Monitor command execution with sub-second precision every 0.1 seconds.
hints: Use decimal intervals for sub-second timing
tasks.explanation: Use precise timing for high-frequency monitoring with the -p option for exact intervals.

tasks.title: Watch Multiple Services
tasks.description: Monitor status of multiple system services in a single view.
tasks.command: watch -n 5 'for service in ssh nginx mysql; do echo "$service: $(systemctl is-active $service 2>/dev/null || echo "not available")"; done'
hints: Use loops to check multiple services
tasks.explanation: Create comprehensive service monitoring dashboards using loops and error handling.

tasks.title: Watch with Custom Dashboard
tasks.description: Create a system monitoring dashboard showing CPU, memory, disk, and network in one view.
tasks.command:
watch -n 2 '
echo "=== System Monitor Dashboard ==="
echo "Time: $(date)"
echo
echo "CPU Usage:"
uptime | awk "{print \$10, \$11, \$12}"
echo
echo "Memory (MB):"
free -m | grep "^Mem" | awk "{printf \"Used: %d, Free: %d, Total: %d\n\", \$3, \$7, \$2}"
echo
echo "Disk Usage:"
df -h / | tail -1 | awk "{printf \"Used: %s (%s), Available: %s\n\", \$3, \$5, \$4}"
echo
echo "Top Processes:"
ps aux --sort=-%cpu | head -4 | tail -3 | awk "{printf \"%s: %.1f%% CPU\n\", \$11, \$3}"
'
tasks.explanation: Create comprehensive monitoring dashboards by combining multiple system commands with formatted output.

tasks.title: Advanced Watch with Alerting
tasks.description: Create an intelligent monitoring system that tracks multiple metrics and provides alerts when thresholds are exceeded.
tasks.command:
watch -n 10 -b '
# System monitoring with thresholds
echo "=== System Health Monitor - $(date) ==="
echo

# CPU Load Alert

if (( $(echo "$LOAD > 2.0" | bc -l) )); then
  echo "âš ï¸  HIGH LOAD ALERT: $LOAD"
else
  echo "âœ… Load Average: $LOAD"
fi

# Memory Usage Alert
MEM_PERCENT=$(free | grep "^Mem" | awk "{printf \"%.0f\", (\$3/\$2)*100}")
if [ $MEM_PERCENT -gt 80 ]; then
  echo "âš ï¸  HIGH MEMORY USAGE: ${MEM_PERCENT}%"
else
  echo "âœ… Memory Usage: ${MEM_PERCENT}%"
fi

# Disk Space Alert
DISK_PERCENT=$(df / | tail -1 | awk "{print \$5}" | sed "s/%//")
if [ $DISK_PERCENT -gt 85 ]; then
  echo "âš ï¸  HIGH DISK USAGE: ${DISK_PERCENT}%"
else
  echo "âœ… Disk Usage: ${DISK_PERCENT}%"
fi

# Process Count Alert
PROC_COUNT=$(ps aux | wc -l)
if [ $PROC_COUNT -gt 200 ]; then
  echo "âš ï¸  HIGH PROCESS COUNT: $PROC_COUNT"
else
  echo "âœ… Process Count: $PROC_COUNT"
fi

echo
echo "Active Alerts:"
ps aux --sort=-%cpu | head -4 | tail -3 | awk "\$3 > 50 {printf \"ðŸ”¥ High CPU: %s (%.1f%%)\n\", \$11, \$3}"
ps aux --sort=-%mem | head -4 | tail -3 | awk "\$4 > 10 {printf \"ðŸ’¾ High Memory: %s (%.1f%%)\n\", \$11, \$4}"
'
tasks.explanation: Create sophisticated monitoring systems with threshold-based alerting, visual indicators, and comprehensive system health checks.
